Meta Lured Young Users, Knowing Risks, States Say

Lawsuits Describe Leaders Rejecting Pleas
From Employees for Safeguards
By NATASHA SINGER In April 2019, David Ginsberg, a
Meta executive, emailed his boss, Meta executive, emailed his boss,
Mark Zuckerberg, with a proposal
to research and reduce loneliness to research and reduce loneliness
and compulsive use on Instagram and compulsive use on Instagram
and Facebook. In the email, Mr. Ginsberg
noted that the company faced scrutiny for its products' influence "especially around areas of prob-
lematic use/addiction and teens" lematic use/addiction and teens.'
He asked Mr. Zuckerberg for 24 engineers, researchers and other
staff, saying Instagram had a "daff, saying Instagram
"defict" on such issues. A week later, Susan Li, now the
company's chief financial officer company's chief financial officer,
informed Mr. Ginsberg that the project was "not funded" because
of stafting constraints. of staffing constraints.
Adam Mosseri, Instagram's
head, ultimately declined to fihead, ultimately declined to fi-
nance the project, too, writing in
an email: "Unfortunately I don't an email: "Unfortunately I don't
see us funding this from Instasee us funding this
gram any time soon."
The email exchanges are just
one slice of evidence cited among more than a dozen lawsuits filed since last year by the attorneys
general of 45 states and the Dis trict of Columbia. The states ac cuse Meta of unfairly ensnaring teenagers and children on Insta-
gram and Facebook while deceiving the public about the hazards. Using a coordinated legal approach reminiscent of the govern-
ment's pursuit of Big Tobacco in the 1990s, the attorneys general seek to compel Meta
protections for minors

of its budget, to Flynns. Since leaving the Trump administration under an ethical cloud,
